alert_summary.description: Ice jam/river ice risk in West Michigan; not a direct road-snow driver for Monday morning but highlights ongoing freeze impacts.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Monday 2026-01-26 in Rockford, MI: no snow or mixed precip is forecast (0" snowfall, 0" liquid). Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (roughly 12–16°F), so any existing snowpack/ice will not melt; however, there is no new accumulation expected to trigger a typical Michigan snow day. Winds are modest (NW/WNW 10–15 mph with higher gusts), mainly adding cold wind chills near/under 0°F during the school commute rather than causing blowing snow. The only commute-relevant flag is a brief visibility dip to around 1 mile near 4–5 AM (likely low cloud/fog/haze), but with no falling snow and light winds at that time, widespread hazardous travel is unlikely. Overall snow-day risk for Monday is very low; the bigger concern would be localized slick spots from residual/packed snow and extreme cold effects (bus reliability, exposed skin), not a storm.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, dry post–Arctic outbreak day: overcast/partly cloudy, no new snow, light-to-moderate NW/WNW wind (generally 5–15 mph), daytime temps in the low-to-mid teens. Main impact is lingering refreeze and cold-exposure risk rather than accumulating snow.

“Bitter cold recovery” pattern: the region goes from extreme cold/wind chills (warning-level) into still-cold but less extreme conditions over 48–72 hours. Schools are more likely to have already made any cold-based closures during the peak cold day(s), not on the moderating day.

Low-visibility pre-dawn/early-morning haze/fog under high humidity and overcast skies with very cold temps (sub-freezing) and light winds. This can create localized slick spots on untreated roads/sidewalks, but usually does not produce widespread closures unless combined with ice/freezing drizzle or significant blowing snow (not present here).

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan is climatologically capable of snow and lake-effect bursts, but many school closures in Michigan are driven by (1) active heavy snowfall during commute hours (often 8–10+ inches with bad timing), (2) ice storms/freezing rain, (3) blizzard conditions with strong winds and whiteouts, or (4) extreme cold/wind chills (often around or below -15°F wind chill thresholds for districts that use cold criteria). Your Monday forecast is cold (teens) but essentially dry with no accumulating snow indicated.
unusual_factors: The broader pattern includes a notable Arctic outbreak (current temp around -15°F with wind chills near -30°F on Saturday, 2026-01-24), which can leave behind widespread hard-packed snow/ice and refreeze issues even on ‘no-precip’ days.

Pre-dawn visibility drops to ~1 mile at 4–5 AM Monday suggest patchy haze/fog/low stratus; this can worsen localized slickness on untreated surfaces (especially bridges/ramps/parking lots) but is typically not enough alone for closure.
Ongoing river ice/ice-jam related alerts in the area indicate prolonged cold impacts, but these are not direct school-transport triggers unless flooding affects routes.

local_microclimates: West Michigan can see localized lake-effect snow bands, but the provided forecast shows 0 snow and no precip signals, so lake-effect impacts look minimal for Rockford on Monday.

Rural/shaded roads and low spots around the Rockford area can hold onto ice longer after extreme cold snaps; even small moisture sources (blowing snow, fog deposition) can create isolated slick patches.
infrastructure_considerations: Because Michigan districts and road crews are accustomed to snow, closures are uncommon on a ‘cold but dry’ day unless there is widespread ice or dangerously low wind chills at bus-stop time.
Wind speeds Monday (max ~14.5 mph, gusts up to low-20s mph at times) are not in the range that typically produces blizzard/whiteout closures without falling/blowing snow.

Morning wind chills are the most relevant operational factor: around 8–10 AM the forecast wind chills hover near 0°F to a few degrees below (not near the ~-15°F wind chill trigger level that more often drives cold closures).
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest terrain variations can contribute to localized icing (valleys/low-lying cold pockets), but there’s no elevation-driven signal here that would outweigh the lack of precipitation and moderate winds.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day likelihood for Rockford on Monday, 2026-01-26 is low based on the provided forecast: no snow/precip, temps in the teens, and wind chills generally near/just below 0°F during the morning commute rather than extreme (-15°F or colder). The main realistic disruption risk is localized slick spots from refreeze/patchy early-morning reduced visibility, which more often leads to slower travel or minor delays than a full closure. Confidence: medium-high, because the forecast is internally consistent (dry all day) and the closure triggers most common in Michigan (heavy snow/ice/blizzard/extreme wind chill) are not strongly present.

safety_recommendations: Snow-day likelihood is LOW for Rockford, MI on Monday, 2026-01-26 based on this forecast (no snow/precip expected; winds not extreme).
Primary risk is PATCHY ICE from refreeze/black ice on untreated surfaces due to temps ~12–16°F all day; have road crews spot-treat bridges, hills, curves, and shaded segments before 6 AM.
Watch for reduced visibility around 4–5 AM (forecast vis ~1 mile). Even without snow, this can slow buses and increase crash risk; consider slightly slower routes and increased following distance.
Prioritize secondary/subdivision streets and bus loop turnarounds (cul-de-sacs) for early treatment; those will stay packed/icy longer than main roads.

Parking lots and sidewalks: pre-treat high-traffic entrances, stairs/ramps, and drop-off zones; enforce salted pathways because cold temps reduce melting effectiveness—use proper cold-weather deicer/salt blend.
Student safety: emphasize cold exposure precautions at bus stops (wind chills near/just below 0°F around/after sunrise). Limit outdoor wait times and ensure contingency for stranded vehicles.
Operational check: confirm buses start reliably in the cold and that drivers have extra time for brake checks and door function at start-of-route.

This provides context that conditions have already been disruptive in the broader region, though it is not a specific Jan 26 closure announcement for Rockford.

news.key_findings_summary: As of Saturday, January 24, 2026, I did not find an official Rockford Public Schools announcement confirming a closure/delay for Monday, January 26, 2026. However, there are meaningful regional disruption signals: Sparta Area School District announced a weather closure for Friday, Jan. 23, and Forest Hills Public Schools reported weather-related cancellations of after-school activities on Thursday, Jan. 22. WMU also closed campuses multiple days this week due to severe wintry weather. Community chatter specifically about Rockford closures for Monday Jan. 26 was not clearly surfaced in the sources captured here, so sentiment remains uncertain and should be rechecked Sunday evening and early Monday morning via official district channels and local closings lists.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: For Monday 2026-01-26, this looks like a 'cold + lingering ice' morning rather than a fresh-snow morning. With no new snow/precip forecast, MDOT trunklines (I-96/US-131/M-44 corridors) should be largely passable, but the main operational issue for K-12 buses will be slick/icy patches on county/local roads (especially bridge decks, shaded corridors, and residential pick-up streets). Kent County Road Commission has indicated active winter operations with substantial staffing and traction-material use during this cold stretch, which supports passability by bus time; however, the very low temps increase the chance that packed ice persists despite treatment. Net: snow day is unlikely from snowfall, but a delay/cautionary decision is still possible if widespread black ice develops overnight or if visibility briefly drops early AM.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For the target school day Monday, 2026-01-26 in Rockford (49341), the provided WeatherAPI forecast shows temps ~12–16°F with wind-driven 'feels like' generally between about 0°F and -4°F during midday/afternoon (worst around ~-4°F). However, a Weather.com hourly panel captured by web crawl shows 'Feels Like' values near -23°F to -24°F (below the -20°F closure trigger) in at least part of its hourly list for Rockford. Weather Underground (as captured) shows current conditions and an Extreme Cold Warning banner but did not expose a Monday-specific 'feels like' value in the captured snippet. Because at least one major public-facing source (Weather.com) shows sub -20°F 'feels like', the closure-trigger condition is met in this verification pass and must be revalidated with a fresh check closer to Monday (and ideally pinned specifically to Mon 1/26 hours 6–9 AM).

primary_factors: No new snow/precip expected (0" forecast); no ice/freezing rain signal
Wind chills for Mon 6–9 AM most likely near 0°F (not at common cold-closure thresholds) after verifier re-check found ≤-20°F evidence was stale/non-target-date
Road risk is mainly residual hard-pack/black ice on residential/subdivision streets and bridge decks; main routes likely passable by ~6:30 AM
No confirmed neighboring-district closures/delays yet for Mon Jan 26; no community buzz indicating an imminent closure call
Power outage risk appears low systemwide with no verified local outage pocket affecting Rockford facilities
final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts align that Monday is a “cold + lingering slick spots” morning, not a storm (no accumulating snow, no freezing rain). Main hazards are patchy black ice and a brief early visibility dip.
2) Disagreement: Only major conflict was the web verifier’s earlier apparent ≤-20°F feels-like trigger from Weather.com. Fresh verifier follow-up indicates those Weather.com values were tied to earlier dates (stale/cached) and are not credible evidence for Mon 1/26 6–9 AM. With that resolved, the consensus remains low closure odds.
3) Plow timing math: With no new snowfall, there’s no ‘snow end → plow buffer’ constraint. Infrastructure indicates priority routes likely in best shape by ~05:30–06:30; residential loops may still have packed/icy patches at 06:30.
4) Any ice? Yes—moderate risk of patchy black ice/refreeze on untreated/shaded surfaces and bridge decks, but not a widespread glaze event.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel found no confirmed Monday closures/delays for Rockford or nearby districts at this time.
6) Power: Power-grid check shows very low systemwide outages and no verified Rockford-specific facility outages.
7) Wind chill trigger: Not confirmed for Monday; most likely near 0°F during bus hours.
8) What would make me wrong: (a) a surprise episode of freezing fog/ice fog producing widespread glaze, (b) an unforecast burst of light snow/lake-effect reducing traction/visibility, (c) a localized but significant Rockford-area power outage impacting school buildings.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology 25% + Web verification 5% → strongly against closure (dry, modest winds; cold but not threshold). Safety 20% + Infrastructure 10% → supports only a small tail risk (patchy ice on residential routes). News 15% → no closure signals to bump up. History 15% → analogs suggest ~3–6% closure; adjusted slightly upward due to residual ice/visibility window. Power 10% → no outage-driven override. Net: 11% snow day probability (more likely normal opening; small chance of a 2-hour delay if black ice/fog verifies worse than expected).

alternative_scenarios.impact: Buses run with slower speeds; spotty slick areas mainly on subdivision streets/bridge decks.

alternative_scenarios.impact: Improves safety margin for bus routes and gives crews more time to abrasive-treat trouble spots.

for_schools: Plan to OPEN but be operationally ready for a LAST-MINUTE DELAY if early-morning road checks find widespread black ice on residential bus routes.
Run 4:30–5:30 AM spot-checks on known trouble spots (bridge decks, shaded hills/curves, subdivision loops) and coordinate with county road commission for abrasive treatment.
Cold-ops checklist: confirm bus start reliability, door/brake function, and communicate bus-stop cold exposure guidance (limit wait times).
for_residents: Assume PATCHY BLACK ICE, especially on neighborhood streets and bridge decks; reduce speed and increase following distance.
Allow extra time 6–8 AM; watch for brief haze/fog around 4–6 AM.
Dress for near/just-below 0°F wind chills at bus stops; minimize exposed skin time.
for_authorities: Prioritize pre-dawn bridge deck/intersection treatment; focus abrasives where salt effectiveness is limited in teens.
If visibility drops materially below ~1 mile, consider targeted advisories for early commuters and bus operations.
Continue monitoring for any localized outage pockets; communicate quickly if any schools lose power/heat.

positions.rationale: For Monday, January 26, 2026 in Rockford, MI, the meteorological setup is a classic post–Arctic outbreak “cold and quiet” day: overcast/partly cloudy, temperatures in the teens, and no new snow/ice indicated. That combination rarely produces a full snow day by itself. The credible meteorological pathways to closure would be (a) unexpectedly widespread dense fog/ice fog reducing visibility much more than forecast during the bus window, or (b) a colder-than-forecast wind chill regime reaching district thresholds, but the provided hourly keeps visibility impacts brief and wind chills generally near 0°F, not -15°F to -20°F. So I’m keeping the snow-day probability low, with a non-zero tail risk for a delay if untreated roads + patchy fog create a notable early-morning travel hazard.
keyFactors: No accumulating precipitation: forecast shows 0" snow and 0" liquid for Mon 2026-01-26, which removes the primary driver for closures in West Michigan.
Winds are modest (max ~14–15 mph, gusts mostly 20–35 mph later) and there’s no falling/blowing snow signal—so no blizzard/whiteout mechanism.
Temperatures are cold but not typically “cold-closure” cold for many MI districts: air temps ~12–16°F with morning wind chills generally around 0°F to a few degrees below.

Only commute-red-flag in the provided hourly is a brief 4–6 AM visibility drop to ~1 mile (likely shallow fog/low stratus). With no precip, that’s more “extra caution/possible minor delay” than a closure trigger.

Residual impacts from the preceding Arctic outbreak (hard-pack/black ice on low-volume roads) could create localized hazards, but absent new snow/ice this usually yields spot issues rather than system-wide closure.

positions.rationale: As the HISTORY specialist, I’m weighting this as a classic low-probability closure setup: no new snow, no freezing rain signal, and winds that aren’t strong enough for drifting/whiteouts. The best historical analogs (“cold, dry post-outbreak” and “recovery day”) produce relatively few full snow days, with outcomes more commonly being normal operations or at most a targeted delay if untreated secondary roads ice up overnight. I land at **6%** to reflect that there *is* a non-zero chance of a local operational decision (especially if residual ice is worse than forecast), but history strongly favors open schools on a day like Mon 2026-01-26.
keyFactors: **Historical closure drivers in West Michigan** are overwhelmingly tied to (a) active heavy snow during commute, (b) ice storms/freezing rain, (c) blizzard/whiteout winds with blowing snow, or (d) *truly extreme* wind chills that cross district thresholds. For Mon 2026-01-26 the provided forecast is dry (0 snow/0 precip) with modest winds, so (a)-(c) are absent.

**“Post–Arctic outbreak, cold-but-quiet Monday” days historically stay open** because districts and road commissions can stabilize conditions once the main storm/ice event has passed. Even when there’s residual pack/black ice risk, it more often yields caution messaging or occasional *delays*, not widespread closures.

**Cold exposure looks below typical closure thresholds for many districts**: morning wind chills near ~0°F to a few degrees below (per the WeatherAPI hours) are uncomfortable but usually not “shutdown” cold in Michigan, especially absent snow/ice precip.

**Residual-conditions wildcard (black ice + low visibility)**: the 4–6 AM visibility dip (~1 mile) plus persistent subfreezing temps could create localized slick spots, but historically this tends to be handled by treatment/route adjustments rather than closure unless it becomes widespread and crash-prone.

**Regional disruption already occurred earlier (Thu/Fri closures/cancellations)**, which actually *reduces* Monday closure odds historically—districts typically close on the peak-impact day(s), then reopen once the pattern turns quiet, even if still very cold.

positions.rationale: From a safety lens, Monday looks like a “cold + lingering slick spots” day rather than a storm day. That usually produces cautions (slower routes, spot-treatment, possibly a delay if crews observe widespread black ice), not a full district-wide closure. I’m keeping the snow-day probability non-zero (12%) mainly because (a) the forecast shows a brief low-visibility window around 4–6 AM when black ice risk is highest, and (b) the region is coming off exceptional cold, which can leave packed/icy neighborhoods that don’t improve by morning. Still, with no forecast snow/ice and only modest winds, a full snow day is more unlikely than likely.
keyFactors: No new snow/ice precipitation expected on Monday 2026-01-26 in the provided hourly forecast (0 precip / 0 snow) → removes the most common closure trigger (accumulation during commute).

Temps stay in the teens all day (roughly 12–16°F) with wind chills near ~0°F to a few degrees below around the commute → cold-stress is real but typically below many districts’ cold-closure thresholds (often nearer -15°F wind chill or colder).

Residual/black ice risk is non-trivial after an Arctic outbreak: untreated secondary roads, bridges, shaded segments, and school lots/sidewalks can remain slick because temps won’t rise above freezing at all.
Brief early-morning visibility reduction (~1 mile around 4–6 AM) could increase crash risk for bus staging/early routes, but it’s short-lived and not paired with active snowfall or high winds.

Operational risks in extreme cold (bus start reliability, diesel gelling, door/brake issues) are a secondary driver for delay/cancel decisions; power-grid risk exists but current outage signal is not strong enough by itself to imply closure.

positions.rationale:
From a news/ops standpoint: I do not see an official Rockford Public Schools announcement for closure/delay for Monday, January 26, 2026, and the supplied forecast for that day is dry with manageable winds. That combination usually means school proceeds, even after a disruptive cold/snow week. I’m not at “near-zero,” though, because (a) the region has had multiple closures recently and (b) extreme cold can leave behind widespread packed snow/black ice on lower-volume roads, which can drive a conservative call if Sunday night refreeze is severe. Net: low chance of a full snow day, modest chance of a delay.

I’m keeping the probability above 10% specifically because of the verifier’s highlighted discrepancy: if a reputable, up-to-date local forecast on Sunday night shows wind chills closer to -15°F to -25°F during bus-stop hours or unexpected light snow/lake-effect, districts may pivot late.
keyFactors: No new precip in the provided Rockford forecast for Mon 2026-01-26 (0.0" snow / 0.0" precip) → removes the most common K-12 closure trigger.
Cold but not typically “cold-closure” level on Monday: temps ~12–16°F and forecast wind chills mostly near 0°F to a few degrees below during the commute (per the provided hourly).

Recent regional disruption signals (WMU closures earlier this week; nearby district operational impacts/closures) raise the baseline slightly, mainly via lingering packed snow/black ice and operational conservatism.
Potential early-morning visibility dip (~1 mile around 4–5 AM) could slow buses and increase crash risk, but without active snow it’s usually “delay/caution” territory, not a full closure.

Data conflict flag: a web-crawled Weather.com panel (not fresh) suggests much lower feels-like temps and even light snow amounts; if that were confirmed with a current timestamp for Mon 6–9 AM, probability would jump.

Not a big probability swing, but worth keeping in the model.
debates.challenge: I agree with the ‘very low’ risk framing, but I think the analysis may underweight how **residual pack + extreme cold can keep secondary roads slick for multiple days**, which historically can trigger *localized* delays even without new precip. Not a big probability swing, but worth keeping in the model.

debates.topic: Your scoring implies a ‘moderate’ morning commute impact (04:00–06:00). Historically, a commute impact that ends by ~06:00 often doesn’t translate into closure unless it’s widespread—can you clarify whether you’re assuming **systemic icing** vs **spotty black ice**? That distinction matters a lot for closures.
debates.challenge: Your scoring implies a ‘moderate’ morning commute impact (04:00–06:00). Historically, a commute impact that ends by ~06:00 often doesn’t translate into closure unless it’s widespread—can you clarify whether you’re assuming **systemic icing** vs **spotty black ice**? That distinction matters a lot for closures.

debates.topic: The closings-list item is useful, but it’s also noisy. I’d caution against treating ‘a Monday closings page exists’ as a leading indicator by itself. Stronger historical signal would be: **specific district pre-announcements** or **NWS winter headlines for Mon morning** (not just hydrologic/river-ice impacts).
debates.challenge: The closings-list item is useful, but it’s also noisy. I’d caution against treating ‘a Monday closings page exists’ as a leading indicator by itself. Stronger historical signal would be: **specific district pre-announcements** or **NWS winter headlines for Mon morning** (not just hydrologic/river-ice impacts).

debates.topic: The forecast shows vis dropping to ~1 mile around 4–5 AM; please clarify whether this is shallow fog/ice fog/low stratus vs. blowing snow, because ice fog can meaningfully raise crash risk on untreated roads even with zero precip.
debates.challenge: The forecast shows vis dropping to ~1 mile around 4–5 AM; please clarify whether this is shallow fog/ice fog/low stratus vs. blowing snow, because ice fog can meaningfully raise crash risk on untreated roads even with zero precip.

debates.topic: Historical closure-rate estimates (3–6%) may underweight ‘post-extreme-cold operational failures’ (bus reliability, diesel issues, staffing) that can drive a delay/closure even without snow; consider adding an operations modifier when temps have been below 0°F for days.
debates.challenge: Historical closure-rate estimates (3–6%) may underweight ‘post-extreme-cold operational failures’ (bus reliability, diesel issues, staffing) that can drive a delay/closure even without snow; consider adding an operations modifier when temps have been below 0°F for days.

debates.topic: The Weather.com ‘feels like -23°F’ and ‘0.1" snow’ discrepancy is significant but the crawl timestamps look several days old and may not be pinned specifically to Mon 1/26 6–9 AM. We should not treat that as a live closure-trigger without a fresh, time-specific verification Sunday night (1/25) or early Monday (1/26).
debates.challenge: The Weather.com ‘feels like -23°F’ and ‘0.1" snow’ discrepancy is significant but the crawl timestamps look several days old and may not be pinned specifically to Mon 1/26 6–9 AM. We should not treat that as a live closure-trigger without a fresh, time-specific verification Sunday night (1/25) or early Monday (1/26).

debates.topic: My own earlier ‘worst conditions 4–6 AM’ is driven mainly by the visibility dip; if that dip disappears in updated forecasts, the closure probability should drop further (toward ~5–8%). If it worsens (sub-1/2 mile) or coincides with any freezing drizzle signal, probability should rise quickly.
debates.challenge: My own earlier ‘worst conditions 4–6 AM’ is driven mainly by the visibility dip; if that dip disappears in updated forecasts, the closure probability should drop further (toward ~5–8%). If it worsens (sub-1/2 mile) or coincides with any freezing drizzle signal, probability should rise quickly.

debates.topic: The writeup treats Monday’s hazard as purely ‘cold + lingering ice’ and downplays the WEBWEATHERVERIFIER discrepancy. Can you sanity-check Monday 6–9 AM wind chill and any lake-effect potential using a fresh, time-stamped source closer to 2026-01-26? If wind chills are materially lower than ~0°F, closure risk changes.

debates.topic: You rate morning commute impact ‘moderate’ and ice risk ‘moderate,’ but that doesn’t clearly translate to an action threshold. What specific roadway/temperature/visibility conditions would move Rockford from “normal” to “2-hour delay” vs “closure” in your framework?
debates.challenge: You rate morning commute impact ‘moderate’ and ice risk ‘moderate,’ but that doesn’t clearly translate to an action threshold. What specific roadway/temperature/visibility conditions would move Rockford from “normal” to “2-hour delay” vs “closure” in your framework?

debates.topic: My own news scan didn’t surface Rockford-specific Monday decisions. I’d like confirmation from a live local closings aggregator (WZZM/WOOD/FOX17 or district channels) Sunday night—otherwise we may be over-weighting regional closures from earlier in the week.
debates.challenge: My own news scan didn’t surface Rockford-specific Monday decisions. I’d like confirmation from a live local closings aggregator (WZZM/WOOD/FOX17 or district channels) Sunday night—otherwise we may be over-weighting regional closures from earlier in the week.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: For Monday, January 26, 2026 in Rockford, MI, the meteorological setup is a classic post–Arctic outbreak “cold and quiet” day: overcast/partly cloudy, temperatures in the teens, and no new snow/ice indicated. That combination rarely produces a full snow day by itself. The credible meteorological pathways to closure would be (a) unexpectedly widespread dense fog/ice fog reducing visibility much more than forecast during the bus window, or (b) a colder-than-forecast wind chill regime reaching district thresholds, but the provided hourly keeps visibility impacts brief and wind chills generally near 0°F, not -15°F to -20°F. So I’m keeping the snow-day probability low, with a non-zero tail risk for a delay if untreated roads + patchy fog create a notable early-morning travel hazard.

As the HISTORY specialist, I’m weighting this as a classic low-probability closure setup: no new snow, no freezing rain signal, and winds that aren’t strong enough for drifting/whiteouts. The best historical analogs (“cold, dry post-outbreak” and “recovery day”) produce relatively few full snow days, with outcomes more commonly being normal operations or at most a targeted delay if untreated secondary roads ice up overnight. I land at **6%** to reflect that there *is* a non-zero chance of a local operational decision (especially if residual ice is worse than forecast), but history strongly favors open schools on a day like Mon 2026-01-26.

From a safety lens, Monday looks like a “cold + lingering slick spots” day rather than a storm day. That usually produces cautions (slower routes, spot-treatment, possibly a delay if crews observe widespread black ice), not a full district-wide closure. I’m keeping the snow-day probability non-zero (12%) mainly because (a) the forecast shows a brief low-visibility window around 4–6 AM when black ice risk is highest, and (b) the region is coming off exceptional cold, which can leave packed/icy neighborhoods that don’t improve by morning. Still, with no forecast snow/ice and only modest winds, a full snow day is more unlikely than likely.

From a news/ops standpoint: I do not see an official Rockford Public Schools announcement for closure/delay for Monday, January 26, 2026, and the supplied forecast for that day is dry with manageable winds. That combination usually means school proceeds, even after a disruptive cold/snow week. I’m not at “near-zero,” though, because (a) the region has had multiple closures recently and (b) extreme cold can leave behind widespread packed snow/black ice on lower-volume roads, which can drive a conservative call if Sunday night refreeze is severe. Net: low chance of a full snow day, modest chance of a delay.

I’m keeping the probability above 10% specifically because of the verifier’s highlighted discrepancy: if a reputable, up-to-date local forecast on Sunday night shows wind chills closer to -15°F to -25°F during bus-stop hours or unexpected light snow/lake-effect, districts may pivot late.

keyDisagreements.topic: News signals (recent closures, regional disruption) are useful context but shouldn’t overweight the Mon 1/26 decision absent a Mon-morning hazard (snow/ice/fog) or an explicit district announcement. I’d treat them as ‘background risk’ only.
positions: News signals (recent closures, regional disruption) are useful context but shouldn’t overweight the Mon 1/26 decision absent a Mon-morning hazard (snow/ice/fog) or an explicit district announcement. I’d treat them as ‘background risk’ only.

keyDisagreements.topic: The ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact seems plausible for localized black ice + brief low vis, but I’d push to quantify whether visibility reduction is truly fog/ice fog vs. just low stratus reporting artifact; if it’s mainly low cloud without surface restriction, commute impact drops.
positions: The ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact seems plausible for localized black ice + brief low vis, but I’d push to quantify whether visibility reduction is truly fog/ice fog vs. just low stratus reporting artifact; if it’s mainly low cloud without surface restriction, commute impact drops.

keyDisagreements.topic: The WEBWEATHERVERIFIER notes a Weather.com crawl showing much colder ‘feels like’ and small snow amounts, but the crawl timestamps appear several days old and may not reflect the latest Mon 1/26 hourly. Before anyone uses a -20°F wind chill trigger, we need a fresh, hour-specific (6–9 AM Mon) verification from a current run.
positions: The WEBWEATHERVERIFIER notes a Weather.com crawl showing much colder ‘feels like’ and small snow amounts, but the crawl timestamps appear several days old and may not reflect the latest Mon 1/26 hourly. Before anyone uses a -20°F wind chill trigger, we need a fresh, hour-specific (6–9 AM Mon) verification from a current run.

keyDisagreements.topic: No major disagreement—historical closure rates cited (3–6%) align with my low single-digit estimate. The ‘seasonal_probability_adjustment’ concept is fine, but I’d avoid large negative adjustments that could mathematically drive probability below realistic tail risk when black ice/fog is present.
positions: No major disagreement—historical closure rates cited (3–6%) align with my low single-digit estimate. The ‘seasonal_probability_adjustment’ concept is fine, but I’d avoid large negative adjustments that could mathematically drive probability below realistic tail risk when black ice/fog is present.

keyDisagreements.topic: I agree with the ‘very low’ risk framing, but I think the analysis may underweight how **residual pack + extreme cold can keep secondary roads slick for multiple days**, which historically can trigger *localized* delays even without new precip. Not a big probability swing, but worth keeping in the model.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 6.0% spread. Average probability: 9%.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Warning issued January 24 at 4:02AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 30 below.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST this morning.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures. An extended period of freezing
temperatures could cause ruptured water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 24 at 5:43AM EST until January 24 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River is possible due to a
suspected ice jam.

* WHERE...Along the Muskegon River in Newaygo County, downriver of
the Croton Dam and near the City of Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Low lying areas along the Muskegon River that are prone
to flooding may see rapidly changing water levels.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 531 AM EST, An ice jam is suspected along the Muskegon
River. The river gauge at Newaygo has reported water levels
rising overnight.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. Flooding due
to freeze-up ice jams is typically minor, but can be
unpredictable.
alert.instruction:
Monitor the river for changes in water level and be prepared to take
action in case flooding develops in flood prone areas. Report
observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and
request they pass this information to the National Weather Service.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 24 at 4:02AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 below.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Eaton, Ingham, Jackson, Allegan, Barry,
Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST this morning.

* IMPACTS...The cold wind chills as low as 15 below zero could
result in hypothermia or frostbite if precautions are not taken.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

Keep pets indoors as much as possible.

Make frequent checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure
portable heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills
inside.
